From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Baseball team in Pennsylvania

This article is about the Major League Baseball team. For other uses, see [Pittsburgh Pirates (disambiguation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates_(disambiguation) "Pittsburgh Pirates (disambiguation)").

"Pittsburgh Allegheny" redirects here. For the minor league team, see [Pittsburgh Allegheny (International Association)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Allegheny_(International_Association) "Pittsburgh Allegheny (International Association)").

| Pittsburgh Pirates |

The **Pittsburgh Pirates** are an American professional [baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baseball "Baseball") team based in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"). The Pirates compete in [Major League Baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League Baseball") (MLB) as a member club of the [National League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_(baseball) "National League (baseball)") (NL) [Central Division](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_Central "National League Central"). Founded as part of the [American Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Association_(19th_century) "American Association (19th century)") in 1881 under the name the Allegheny Base Ball Club of Pittsburgh, the club joined the National League in 1887 and was a member of the [National League East](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_East "National League East") from 1969 through 1993. The Pirates have won five [World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Series "World Series") championships, nine [National League pennants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_National_League_pennant_winners "List of National League pennant winners"), nine National League East division titles and made three appearances in the [Wild Card Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_Wild_Card_Game "Major League Baseball Wild Card Game").

The Pirates were among the best teams in baseball at the start of the 20th century, playing in the [inaugural World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1903_World_Series "1903 World Series") in 1903 and winning their first title in [1909](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1909_World_Series "1909 World Series") behind [Honus Wagner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honus_Wagner "Honus Wagner"). The Pirates took part in arguably the most famous World Series ending, winning the [1960 World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1960_World_Series "1960 World Series") against the [New York Yankees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Yankees "New York Yankees") on a [walk-off home run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walk-off_home_run "Walk-off home run") by [Bill Mazeroski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Mazeroski "Bill Mazeroski"), the only time that Game 7 of the World Series has ever ended with a home run. They won again in [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_World_Series "1971 World Series") behind [Roberto Clemente](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Clemente "Roberto Clemente"), the first Latin-American enshrined in the [National Baseball Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Baseball_Hall_of_Fame "National Baseball Hall of Fame"), and in [1979](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_World_Series "1979 World Series") under the leadership of [Willie Stargell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willie_Stargell "Willie Stargell").

Since their last World Series in 1979, the Pirates have largely endured a period of great struggle. Since then, they have only had eleven winning seasons, six postseason appearances, three division titles, and have advanced just once in the postseason with a victory in the 2013 National League Wild Card Game. The Pirates additionally posted a losing record in 20 consecutive seasons from [1993](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1993 Pittsburgh Pirates season") to [2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "2012 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), a record streak in both MLB and the four major North American professional sports leagues.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-5)
The Pirates currently have the fifth-longest World Series championship drought, the longest pennant drought in the National League,[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-6) and the longest [League Championship Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_Championship_Series "League Championship Series") appearance and division championship drought in all of baseball. From 1882 to 2025, the Pirates have an overall record of 10,910–10,910–140 (.500 winning 'percentage').[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-7)

The Pirates are also often referred to as the "Bucs" or the "Buccos" (derived from [buccaneer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buccaneer "Buccaneer"), a synonym for [pirate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piracy "Piracy")). Since 2001 the team has played its home games at [PNC Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Park "PNC Park"), a 39,000-seat stadium along the [Allegheny River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_River "Allegheny River") in Pittsburgh's [North Side](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Side_(Pittsburgh) "North Side (Pittsburgh)"). The Pirates previously played at [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field") from 1909 to 1970 and at [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium") from 1970 to 2000. Since 1948 the Pirates' colors have been black, gold and white, derived from the [flag of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Pittsburgh "Flag of Pittsburgh") and matching the other major professional sports teams in Pittsburgh, the [Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") and the [Penguins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins").

## History

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")\]

Main article: [History of the Pittsburgh Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Pittsburgh_Pirates "History of the Pittsburgh Pirates")

Professional baseball in the Pittsburgh area began in 1876 with the organization of the [Allegheny Base Ball Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Allegheny_(International_Association) "Pittsburgh Allegheny (International Association)"), an independent (non-league) club based in a then-separate city called [Allegheny City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny,_Pennsylvania "Allegheny, Pennsylvania"), across the [Allegheny River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_River "Allegheny River") from Pittsburgh. The team joined the minor league [International Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Association_for_Professional_Base_Ball_Players "International Association for Professional Base Ball Players") in 1877, only to fold the following season.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-8) On October 15, 1881, [Denny McKnight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denny_McKnight "Denny McKnight") held a meeting at Pittsburgh's St. Clair Hotel to organize a new Allegheny club,[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-9) which began play in 1882 as a founding member of the [American Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Association_(19th_century) "American Association (19th century)"). Chartered as the Allegheny Base Ball Club of Pittsburgh,[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-10) the team was listed as "Allegheny" in the standings, and was sometimes called the "Alleghenys" (occasionally the "Alleghenies" or “Allies”) in that era's custom of referring to a team by its pluralized city or club name. After five mostly mediocre seasons, Pittsburgh became the first [A.A. team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_North_American_professional_sports_teams "Major North American professional sports teams") to switch to the older [National League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_(baseball) "National League (baseball)") in 1887.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-11)

During the winter prior to the 1890 season, almost all of the Alleghenys' best players bolted to the [Players' League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Players%27_League "Players' League")'s [Pittsburgh Burghers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Burghers "Pittsburgh Burghers"). The Players' League collapsed after the season, and the players were allowed to go back to their old clubs. However, the Alleghenys also signed highly regarded second baseman [Lou Bierbauer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lou_Bierbauer "Lou Bierbauer"), who had previously played with the A.A.'s [Philadelphia Athletics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Athletics_(American_Association) "Philadelphia Athletics (American Association)"). Although the Athletics failed to include Bierbauer on their reserve list, they loudly protested the Alleghenys' move. In an official complaint, an AA official claimed the Alleghenys' signing of Bierbauer was "piratical".[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-12) This incident quickly accelerated into a schism between the leagues that contributed to the demise of the A.A. Although the Alleghenys were never found guilty of wrongdoing, their allegedly "piratical" act gained them the occasional nickname "Pirates" from newspapers around the country, starting in 1891. Within a few years, the nickname caught on with even Pittsburgh newspapers.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-13) The nickname was first acknowledged on the team's uniforms in 1912.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/1909_Pittsburgh_Pirates_on_a_boat_FINAL.jpg/250px-1909_Pittsburgh_Pirates_on_a_boat_FINAL.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:1909_Pittsburgh_Pirates_on_a_boat_FINAL.jpg) The [1909 Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1909_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1909 Pittsburgh Pirates season") in a poster celebrating their National League pennant. [Frank Chance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Chance "Frank Chance") of Chicago and [John McGraw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McGraw "John McGraw") of New York, two teams the Pirates beat for the pennant, are being made to [walk the plank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walk_the_plank "Walk the plank").

Early on, the Pirates organization finished no higher than 2nd in either league’s standings, but their fortunes began to change at the turn of the 20th century. The Pirates acquired several star players from the [Louisville Colonels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisville_Colonels "Louisville Colonels"), who were slated for elimination when the N.L. contracted from 12 to 8 teams. (The franchises did not formally consolidate; the player acquisitions were separate transactions.)[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-TBT-14) Among those players was [Honus Wagner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honus_Wagner "Honus Wagner"), who would become one of the first players inducted to the [Baseball Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baseball_Hall_of_Fame "Baseball Hall of Fame"). The Pirates were among the best teams in baseball in the early 1900s, winning three consecutive National League pennants from 1901 to 1903 and participating in [the first modern World Series ever played](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1903_World_Series "1903 World Series"), which they lost to [Boston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1903_Boston_Americans_season "1903 Boston Americans season"). The Pirates returned to the World Series in [1909](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1909_World_Series "1909 World Series"), defeating the [Detroit Tigers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1909_Detroit_Tigers_season "1909 Detroit Tigers season") for their first-ever world title. That year, the Pirates moved from [Exposition Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exposition_Park_(Pittsburgh) "Exposition Park (Pittsburgh)") to one of the first steel and concrete ballparks, [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field").

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/55/World_Series_program_%281927%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:World_Series_program_(1927).jpg) 1927 World Series program

As Wagner aged, the Pirates began to slip down the National League standings in the 1910s, culminating in a disastrous 51–103 record in 1917; however, veteran outfielder [Max Carey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Carey "Max Carey") and young players [Pie Traynor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pie_Traynor "Pie Traynor") and [Kiki Cuyler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiki_Cuyler "Kiki Cuyler"), along with a remarkably deep pitching staff, brought the Pirates back to relevance in the 1920s. The Pirates won their second title in [1925](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_World_Series "1925 World Series"), becoming the first team to come back from a 3–1 deficit in the World Series.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-15) The Pirates returned to the World Series in [1927](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1927_World_Series "1927 World Series") but were swept by the [Murderer's Row](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murderer%27s_Row "Murderer's Row") [Yankees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Yankees "New York Yankees"). The Pirates remained a competitive team through the 1930s but failed to win the pennant, coming closest in 1938 when they were passed by the [Chicago Cubs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Cubs "Chicago Cubs") in the [final week of the season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_in_the_Gloamin%27 "Homer in the Gloamin'").

Despite the prowess of [Ralph Kiner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Kiner "Ralph Kiner") as a slugger during the latter half of the stretch, the Pirates were mostly undistinguished in the 1940s, and downright awful in the early 1950s. [Branch Rickey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_Rickey "Branch Rickey") was brought in during this time to rebuild the team, which returned to the World Series in [1960](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1960_World_Series "1960 World Series"). They were largely outscored over the course of the series by the [Yankees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1960_New_York_Yankees_season "1960 New York Yankees season"), yet the Pirates won on a walk-off home run by [Bill Mazeroski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Mazeroski "Bill Mazeroski") in the bottom of the 9th inning in Game 7. As of 2024, it is the only Game 7 walk-off home run in World Series history.

Led by right fielder [Roberto Clemente](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Clemente "Roberto Clemente"), the Pirates remained a strong team throughout the 1960s but did not return to the World Series until [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_World_Series "1971 World Series"). Playing in the new [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium"), the Pirates defeated the favored [Baltimore Orioles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_Baltimore_Orioles_season "1971 Baltimore Orioles season") behind Clemente's hitting and the pitching of [Steve Blass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Blass "Steve Blass"). In the same year on September 1, the Pirates became the first team to field an all-Black and Latino lineup.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-16)
Despite Clemente's death after the 1972 season, the Pirates were one of the dominant teams of the decade, winning the newly created [National League East](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_East "National League East") in [1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1970 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1971 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), [1972](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1972_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1972 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), [1974](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1974_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1974 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), [1975](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1975_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1975 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), and [1979](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1979 Pittsburgh Pirates season"). Powered by sluggers such as [Willie Stargell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willie_Stargell "Willie Stargell"), [Dave Parker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Parker "Dave Parker"), and [Al Oliver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Oliver "Al Oliver"), the team was nicknamed "The Lumber Company." Behind Stargell's leadership and the [disco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disco "Disco") song ["We Are Family"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/We_Are_Family_(song) "We Are Family (song)") (which the team adopted as its theme song), the Pirates came back from a 3–1 deficit to once again defeat the [Orioles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_Baltimore_Orioles_season "1979 Baltimore Orioles season") in the [1979 World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_World_Series "1979 World Series") for the franchise's fifth championship. During the 1979 championship season, a Pittsburgh player was designated as Most Valuable Player in every available category: All-Star Game MVP (Dave Parker), NLCS MVP (Willie Stargell), World Series MVP (Willie Stargell), and National League MVP (Willie Stargell, shared with Keith Hernandez of St. Louis).

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f6/Pirates1989.jpg/250px-Pirates1989.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pirates1989.jpg) Pittsburgh clinching the division title in 1990.

The Pirates sank back into mediocrity in the 1980s and returned to post-season play in the early 1990s behind young players like [Barry Bonds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barry_Bonds "Barry Bonds"), [Bobby Bonilla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bobby_Bonilla "Bobby Bonilla"), and [Doug Drabek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doug_Drabek "Doug Drabek"). The Pirates won three straight division titles from 1990 to 1992 but lost in the [National League Championship Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_Championship_Series "National League Championship Series") each time, notably coming within one out of advancing to the World Series in [1992](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992_National_League_Championship_Series "1992 National League Championship Series"). Several of the team's best players, including Bonds and Drabek, left as free agents after that season.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Andrew_McCutchen_on_June_12%2C_2012.jpg/250px-Andrew_McCutchen_on_June_12%2C_2012.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andrew_McCutchen_on_June_12,_2012.jpg) [Andrew McCutchen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_McCutchen "Andrew McCutchen"), 2012

With salaries rising across baseball, the small-market Pirates struggled to keep pace with the sport and they posted a losing record for 20 consecutive seasons, a record among North American professional sports teams. Even the opening of a new stadium in 2001, [PNC Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Park "PNC Park"), did little to change the team's fortunes. The Pirates finally returned to the postseason in [2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "2013 Pittsburgh Pirates season") behind National League MVP [Andrew McCutchen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_McCutchen "Andrew McCutchen"), defeating the [Cincinnati Reds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Cincinnati_Reds_season "2013 Cincinnati Reds season") in the [Wild Card Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_National_League_Wild_Card_Game "2013 National League Wild Card Game"). They were eliminated in five games in the [next round](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_National_League_Division_Series "2013 National League Division Series") by the [St. Louis Cardinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis Cardinals"). That season, the Pirates also became the seventh MLB team to reach 10,000 all-time wins.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-17) On [Opening Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opening_Day "Opening Day") 2015 the Pirates' loss was the team's 10,000th[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-Wilmoth,_Charlie_2015-18) making the Pirates the fourth MLB team to achieve this distinction, following the [Philadelphia Phillies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies "Philadelphia Phillies"), [Atlanta Braves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta Braves"), and the Chicago Cubs.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-19) The Pirates returned to the postseason in 2014 and 2015 and lost the Wild Card game both times and have not qualified for the playoffs since then.

## Ballpark

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Ballpark")\]

Since 2001, the Pirates have played their home games at [PNC Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Park "PNC Park"), located on the banks of the [Allegheny River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_River "Allegheny River") in Pittsburgh's North Side neighborhood. The park was built as a replacement for the aging [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium"), a dual-purpose stadium that had been designed for functionality rather than aesthetics.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-OnDeck-20) Funded mainly through taxpayer money, the ballpark cost $216 million to construct and is named for Pittsburgh-based [PNC Financial Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Financial_Services "PNC Financial Services").[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-21) PNC Park's listed capacity is 38,747 for baseball, although standing-room only space can accommodate more than 40,000 fans; the biggest crowd in stadium history was the [2015 National League Wild Card Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_National_League_Wild_Card_Game "2015 National League Wild Card Game"), when 40,889 fans saw the Cubs defeat the Pirates 4–0.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/PNC_Park_%2816190813495%29.jpg/250px-PNC_Park_%2816190813495%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PNC_Park_(16190813495).jpg) PNC Park prior to a game in 2014

Widely considered to be among the best baseball stadiums in the country, several outlets have praised PNC Park for its location, limestone and steel façade, and views of both the action on the field and the Pittsburgh skyline.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-kdka15-22)[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-wapo2017-23)[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-24)[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-25) PNC Park was the first two-deck ballpark to be built in the United States since Milwaukee County Stadium opened in 1953;[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-ESPN-26) as a result, fans in the upper deck are closer to the action than at most ballparks, with the highest seat in the stadium 88 feet (27 m) above the playing surface. Fans in the lower deck are also closer to the field: the batter is closer to the seats behind home plate than to the pitcher,[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-27) and seating along the baselines is 45 feet from the bases at their closest point. A four-level steel rotunda down the left field line offers extensive standing room only space, and action on the field can be seen from the first-level concourse. PNC Park has a reputation as a pitcher's park, with a deep left field that juts out to more than 410 feet from home plate. Right field is closer, but the wall is 21 feet high, nicknamed the Clemente Wall after former right-fielder [Roberto Clemente](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Clemente "Roberto Clemente"), who wore number 21. Statutes of Clemente, [Willie Stargell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willie_Stargell "Willie Stargell"), [Bill Mazeroski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Mazeroski "Bill Mazeroski") and [Honus Wagner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honus_Wagner "Honus Wagner") are located at several entrances to the stadium. In addition to hosting Pirate games, PNC Park hosted the [2006 MLB All-Star Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_MLB_All-Star_Game "2006 MLB All-Star Game") and has been the site of several concerts.

PNC Park is located near several major highways and parking is available in the blocks around the ballpark. Fans can also walk to the stadium from [downtown Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Pittsburgh "Downtown Pittsburgh") via the [Clemente Bridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clemente_Bridge "Clemente Bridge"), or take [Pittsburgh Light Rail](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Light_Rail "Pittsburgh Light Rail") to the system's [North Side station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Side_station_(Pittsburgh_Regional_Transit) "North Side station (Pittsburgh Regional Transit)"), located just outside the stadium's home plate entrance.

### Former ballparks

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Former ballparks")\]

The Pirates' first home was [Exposition Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exposition_Park_(Pittsburgh) "Exposition Park (Pittsburgh)"), located a couple blocks west of the current location of PNC Park. The Pirates split their early years between that ballpark and [Recreation Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recreation_Park_(Pittsburgh) "Recreation Park (Pittsburgh)"), which was located further inland from the flood-prone Allegheny River. The Pirates moved back to Exposition Park for good in 1891, and remained there until the middle of the 1909 season.[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-28) The park hosted the [first modern World Series ever played](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1903_World_Series "1903 World Series") in 1903, but by the end of the decade the wooden structure was too small for the Pirates' growing fanbase. Exposition Park hosted several minor league teams before being razed prior to 1920.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-29) The site, currently occupied by a parking lot and several restaurants, is marked by a state historical marker (near the intersection of West Gen. Robinson Street and Tony Dorsett Drive) and a sunken home plate marker made of steel (a few paces away, in the parking lot) , both noting the 1903 World Series.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Forbes_Field_exterior.jpg/250px-Forbes_Field_exterior.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Forbes_Field_exterior.jpg) [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field"), the Pirates' home ballpark from 1909 to 1970

In the middle of the 1909 season, the Pirates moved into [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field") in [Oakland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_(Pittsburgh) "Oakland (Pittsburgh)"), which would serve as the club's home for the next 61 years. Built at a cost of $1 million, the park was the first three-tiered steel-and-concrete ballpark in the nation.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-30) Forbes Field was expanded several times over the decades, with capacity almost doubled from its initial 23,000 in 1909 to 41,000 in 1925 (although it was reduced to 35,000 in its later years). Pirates owner Barney Dreyfuss "hated cheap [home runs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_run "Home run") and vowed he'd have none in his park", which led him to design a large playing field for Forbes Field.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-31) When a large grandstand was constructed down the right field line in the early 1920s, reducing the distance to 300 feet from home plate, Dreyfuss had a 28-foot screen erected.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-32)[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-33)[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-34) Despite this, Forbes Field is remembered for several famous home runs: the final three homers of [Babe Ruth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Babe_Ruth "Babe Ruth")'s career on May 25, 1935[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-Dia90-35) and Bill Mazeroski's championship-winning blast in Game 7 of the [1960 World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1960_World_Series "1960 World Series"). The park also hosted [football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_football "American football") games for the [Pittsburgh Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") and [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh") ["Pitt" Panthers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers_football "Pittsburgh Panthers football"). Located in a sparsely populated area of the city when it opened in 1909, by the 1960s Forbes Field was surrounded by the University of Pittsburgh campus. The Pirates left the ballpark midway through the 1970 season and the stadium was demolished the following year. Sections of the outfield wall remain standing along Roberto Clemente Drive, and the home plate used in the stadium's final game remains preserved in the University of Pittsburgh's [Posvar Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wesley_W._Posvar_Hall "Wesley W. Posvar Hall").[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-Restor-36)[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-37)

The Pirates moved into the multipurpose [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium") in 1970, which they shared with the Steelers. Like other [multi-purpose stadiums](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-purpose_stadium "Multi-purpose stadium") popular at the time, Three Rivers featured extensive box seats, a turf playing field, and moveable seating sections to accommodate both football and baseball. Three Rivers ended up being much better suited for the former than the latter, and the Pirates struggled to draw fans despite their on-field success in the 1970s. By the 1990s, the Pirates were threatening to leave Pittsburgh unless a new, baseball-only stadium was constructed. The Pirates played their final game at Three Rivers on October 1, 2000, and the stadium was demolished the following winter. The site is currently occupied by parking lots and [Stage AE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stage_AE "Stage AE"), although one of the stadium's entrance markers remains standing near [Acrisure Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acrisure_Stadium "Acrisure Stadium"). In 2012, members of the [Society for American Baseball Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_American_Baseball_Research "Society for American Baseball Research") marked and painted the [home plate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baseball_field#Home_base "Baseball field") and first base of the former stadium on the 40th Anniversary of Roberto Clemente's 3,000th hit.[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-38) Since then, markers have been placed at the locations of home plate, second base, and the pitcher’s plate.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/BuccoSpringTraining.JPG/250px-BuccoSpringTraining.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BuccoSpringTraining.JPG) [LECOM Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LECOM_Park "LECOM Park"), which hosts the Pirates' Spring Training games

### Spring Training

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Spring Training")\]

Since 1969, the Pirates have held [Spring Training](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_Training "Spring Training") at [LECOM Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LECOM_Park "LECOM Park") in [Bradenton, Florida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bradenton,_Florida "Bradenton, Florida"), which is also used for the Pirates' minor league team, the [Bradenton Marauders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bradenton_Marauders "Bradenton Marauders"). Constructed in 1923, LECOM Park is the oldest stadium still in use for Spring Training and the second-oldest minor league park, behind only [Jackie Robinson Ballpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackie_Robinson_Ballpark "Jackie Robinson Ballpark") in [Daytona Beach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytona_Beach "Daytona Beach"), which dates to 1914.[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-39) It is also the third oldest stadium currently used by a major league team after [Fenway Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fenway_Park "Fenway Park"), built in 1912, and [Wrigley Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wrigley_Field "Wrigley Field"), built in 1914.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-40) Built in a Florida Spanish Mission style, LECOM Park underwent two major renovations in 1993 and 2008, the latter of which added lights.[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-41) The park was formerly named "McKechnie Field," for Bradenton resident and Baseball Hall of Fame great [Bill McKechnie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_McKechnie "Bill McKechnie"), who led the Pirates in [1925](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_World_Series "1925 World Series"); since 2017 it has been named for the [Lake Erie College of Osteopathic Medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Erie_College_of_Osteopathic_Medicine "Lake Erie College of Osteopathic Medicine"), which has its main campus in [Erie, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erie,_Pennsylvania "Erie, Pennsylvania"), and also a campus in Bradenton.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-lecom-42) [Pirate City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirate_City "Pirate City"), the site of the Pirates' Spring Training complex, is located a few miles east of LECOM Park.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Jim_Russell-_Pittsburgh_Pirate.jpg/250px-Jim_Russell-_Pittsburgh_Pirate.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Jim_Russell-_Pittsburgh_Pirate.jpg) Uniform design in the 1940s

The Pirates have had many uniforms and logo changes over the years, with the only consistency being the "P" on the team's cap. Like other teams in Major League Baseball, the Pirates predominantly favored a patriotic red, white and blue color scheme through the first half of the 20th Century.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-sportslogos.net-43) During this time, the Pirates predominantly wore a blue cap, with either a red or white P. The uniforms were plain, often including a simple "P" if anything at all. The team's name was first acknowledged in 1912, with a pinstripe jersey that had "Pirates" running vertically down the placket.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-sportslogos.net-43) The team's name would not appear on the club's uniforms again until they were added to the road uniforms in 1933, this time written horizontally in a more ornate style. An image of a pirate's head appeared on the home and road jerseys for the 1940 and 1941 seasons (this image would be reused for the team's logo in the 1980s and 1990s), and "Pittsburgh" first appeared on the road uniforms in 1942.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-sportslogos.net-43)

In 1948, the team broke away from the patriotic "Red, White, & Blue" color scheme when they adopted the current black & gold color scheme, to match that of the colors of the [Flag of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Pittsburgh "Flag of Pittsburgh") and, to a lesser extent at the time, the colors of the then-relatively unknown [Pittsburgh Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") of the [National Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League"). The Pirates had made a similar change to black and gold in 1924,[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-44)[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-45)[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-46) but the change did not last beyond that season.[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-47)[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-48) Along with the [San Francisco Giants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants "San Francisco Giants"), the Pirates are one of two pre-expansion [National League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_(baseball) "National League (baseball)") teams that completely changed their colors, although red returned as an "accent color" in 1997 and remained until 2009.

In the late 1950s, the team adopted sleeveless jerseys. While not an innovation by the team (the honor goes to the [Cincinnati Reds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds "Cincinnati Reds")), the Pirates helped popularize the look. Coinciding with the move into [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium") in 1970, the team switched to a darker shade of gold and changed their caps from black to gold with a black brim; they also introduced pullover nylon/cotton jerseys and beltless pants as part of their new uniform set (later to become polyester doubleknit).[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-sportslogos.net-43) The Pirates became the first team in baseball to sport such a look, but it quickly became popular throughout the league, and the pullover style would become the prominent look of 1970s and 1980s baseball. The Pirates ditched the pullover style in favor of the traditional button-down style in 1991, one of the last teams to switch.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Fred_Rogers_and_Willie_Stargell.jpg/250px-Fred_Rogers_and_Willie_Stargell.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Fred_Rogers_and_Willie_Stargell.jpg) [Willie Stargell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willie_Stargell "Willie Stargell") wearing the black top and gold pants combo, posing with Pittsburgh native [Fred Rogers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Rogers "Fred Rogers")

In 1976, the National League celebrated its 100th anniversary. To coincide with it, certain NL teams wore old-style pillbox hats complete with horizontal [pinstripes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinstripes "Pinstripes"). After the season, the Pirates were the only team to adopt the hats permanently, alternating between a black hat and a gold hat for several seasons.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-sportslogos.net-43) The Pirates switched back to a brighter shade of gold for the 1977 season, and became one of the first teams to wear [third jerseys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_jersey "Third jersey"), following the [Oakland Athletics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_Athletics "Oakland Athletics"). Starting in [1977](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1977_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1977 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), the Pirates had uniform styles which included two different caps and three different uniforms: an all-black set, an all-gold set, and a white set with black-and-gold pinstripes. The pants, tops and caps could all be worn interchangeably for different looks; the Pirates wore four different uniform combinations in the [1979 World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_World_Series "1979 World Series"). The pinstripes came off the white uniforms in 1980, but the Pirates continued to utilize the three uniform set until the 1985 season, when the team returned to the straightforward home whites/road grays combination. The solid black cap with a gold "P" returned in 1987 and has been the team's primary cap ever since.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-sportslogos.net-43)

After [Kevin McClatchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_McClatchy "Kevin McClatchy") purchased the team in 1996, the Pirates added a third jersey and utilized red as an accent color, including red brims on the team's caps. A sleeveless white jersey with pinstripes was worn as an alternate home jersey from 2005 to 2010, and a red alternate jersey was added for the 2007 and 2008 seasons. In [2009](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "2009 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), the Pirates began wearing an alternate black jersey with a gold "P" at both home and on the road.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-sportslogos.net-43) From 2013 to 2019, the Pirates wore throwback uniforms for Sunday home games: the early 70s pullover uniforms from 2013 to 2015, and the gold top/black pants from the late 70s from 2016 to 2019.[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-49)

Since the [2015 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "2015 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), the Pirates have worn an alternate camo jersey for select home games.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-50) The camouflage alternates were updated for the [2018 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "2018 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), now white with camo green wordmarks, numbers, piping, and patches.[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-51)

Ahead of the [2020 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "2020 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), the Pirates revived the script "Pittsburgh" wordmarks on their gray road and new black alternate road jerseys, which were unveiled on January 24, 2020. Script wordmarks had previously been seen on the road jerseys from 1990 until 2000. The alternate road jersey also features a Pirate wearing a re-colored bandana, yellow to match the theme of the jersey, and is worn with a black cap featuring the "P" logo outlined in black and yellow.[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-52) In addition to these road uniforms, the Pirates continue to wear their white uniforms, the black alternate with the gold "P", and the camo alternate for games played at PNC Park.

In 2023, the Pirates retired the camo home alternate to comply with the new "4+1" rule, restricting teams to a home, away, two alternate uniforms and a [City Connect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_Connect "City Connect") uniform. The Pirates continued to wear the camo cap on occasion with the home white uniform. They also unveiled their City Connect uniform, featuring a gold top and black pants with a gold "P" cap with black brim. The jersey itself features the abbreviation of Pittsburgh "PGH". A closer look of the jersey feature the Three Elements. The inverted "Y", representing the three rivers that meet in Pittsburgh ( [Allegheny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_River "Allegheny River"), [Monongahela](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monongahela_River "Monongahela River"), and [Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio River")). The astroid, or the diamond shape star represents the famous "Steelmark" logo and the Check or the Checkbox, represents the Seal of Pittsburgh.[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-53)

## Rivalries

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Rivalries")\]

### Philadelphia Phillies

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Philadelphia Phillies")\]

Main article: [Phillies–Pirates rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phillies%E2%80%93Pirates_rivalry "Phillies–Pirates rivalry")

The rivalry between the [Philadelphia Phillies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies "Philadelphia Phillies") and the Pirates was considered by some to be one of the best rivalries in the National League until 1994.[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-54)[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-LostRivalry-55)[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-PhilliesPirates-56) It began when the Pittsburgh Pirates entered the NL in 1887, four years after the Phillies.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-PhilliesRealignment-57)

The Phillies and the Pirates remained together after the National League split into two divisions in 1969. During the period of two-division play (1969–1993), the two [National League East](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_East "National League East") division rivals won the two highest numbers of division championships, reigning almost exclusively as NL East champions in the 1970s and again in the early 1990s.[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-PhilliesPirates-56)[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-MostTitles-58)[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-59) The Pirates nine, the Phillies six; together, the two teams' 15 championships accounted for more than half of the 25 NL East championships during that span.[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-MostTitles-58)

After the Pirates moved to the [National League Central](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_Central "National League Central") in 1994, the teams face each other only in two series each year and the rivalry has diminished.[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-LostRivalry-55)[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-PhilliesPirates-56) However, many fans, especially older ones, retain their dislike for the other team, with regional differences between [Eastern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_metropolitan_area "Philadelphia metropolitan area") and [Western Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Pennsylvania "Western Pennsylvania") still fueling the rivalry.[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-60)

### Cincinnati Reds

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Cincinnati Reds")\]

Main article: [Pirates-Reds rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirates-Reds_rivalry "Pirates-Reds rivalry")

The Pirates' biggest divisional rival is the [Cincinnati Reds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds "Cincinnati Reds"), given the two teams' proximity, the carryover of the cities' [football rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bengals%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Bengals–Steelers rivalry"), and the fact that the Reds and Pirates have met six times in the postseason,[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-61) most recently in the [2013 National League Wild Card Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_National_League_Wild_Card_Game "2013 National League Wild Card Game"). In the 2010s, the two teams frequently [hit each other with pitches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hit_by_pitch "Hit by pitch"), occasionally resulting in brawls.[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-62)

### Divisional foes

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Divisional foes")\]

From 2013 to 2015, the Pirates battled with the [St. Louis Cardinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis Cardinals") for the Central Division title, with the Cardinals narrowly winning the division each year. The two teams faced off in the [2013 National League Division Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_National_League_Division_Series "2013 National League Division Series"), which the Cardinals won in five games. The Pirates had a contentious[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-63) battle with the [Milwaukee Brewers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milwaukee_Brewers "Milwaukee Brewers") for a Wild Card spot in 2014 and faced off against the [Chicago Cubs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Cubs "Chicago Cubs") in the [2015 National League Wild Card Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_National_League_Wild_Card_Game "2015 National League Wild Card Game"). The Cubs were major rivals for the Pirates earlier in their history, as both were among the best teams in baseball in the early 1900s and the Cubs eliminated the Pirates from the pennant race in the last week of
[the 1938 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_in_the_Gloamin%27 "Homer in the Gloamin'").

### Interleague

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Interleague")\]

The Pirates play an annual [interleague](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interleague_play "Interleague play") series against the [Detroit Tigers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit_Tigers "Detroit Tigers"). While the Pirates and Tigers only became "natural rivals" because the other AL and NL Central teams were already paired up, it has become popular with fans of both teams, possibly due to the rivalry between the [National Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League")'s [Detroit Red Wings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit_Red_Wings "Detroit Red Wings") and [Pittsburgh Penguins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins"). The two teams have several other connections as well. The Tigers' AA Minor League affiliate, the [Erie SeaWolves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erie_SeaWolves "Erie SeaWolves"), located near Pittsburgh, is a former affiliate of the Pirates and has retained the logo of a wolf wearing a pirate bandanna and eye patch. Additionally, Jim Leyland, former manager of both the Pirates (1986–1996) and the Tigers (2005–2013), remains popular in Pittsburgh where he resides. The Pirates led the regular-season series, 36–29. The two teams played in the [1909 World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1909_World_Series "1909 World Series").

An on-and-off rivalry with the [Cleveland Guardians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Guardians "Cleveland Guardians") stems from the close proximity of both cities, and features some carryover elements from the [longstanding rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Browns%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Browns–Steelers rivalry") in the [National Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") between the [Cleveland Browns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns") and [Pittsburgh Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers"). Because the Guardians' designated interleague rival is the Reds and the Pirates' designated rival is the Tigers, the teams have only played periodically. The teams played one three-game series each year from 1997 to 2001 and periodically between 2002 and 2022, generally only in years in which the AL Central played the NL Central in the former interleague play rotation. The teams played six games in 2020 as MLB instituted an abbreviated schedule focusing on regional match-ups. Beginning in 2023, the teams will play a three-game series each season as a result of the new "balanced" schedule. The Pirates lead the series 21–19.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-64)

Hall of Famer [Roberto Clemente](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Clemente "Roberto Clemente") collected 3,000 hits and was named [World Series MVP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Series_MVP "World Series MVP") in 1971[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/RalphKiner1953bowman.jpg/250px-RalphKiner1953bowman.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:RalphKiner1953bowman.jpg) Hall of Famer [Ralph Kiner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Kiner "Ralph Kiner") led the NL in home runs for seven straight seasons (1946–1952)[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Bill_Mazeroski_-_Pittsburgh_Pirates_-_1966.jpg/250px-Bill_Mazeroski_-_Pittsburgh_Pirates_-_1966.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bill_Mazeroski_-_Pittsburgh_Pirates_-_1966.jpg) Hall of Famer [Bill Mazeroski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Mazeroski "Bill Mazeroski") hit a ninth-inning walk-off home run that decided the 1960 World Series[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Willie_Stargell_-_Pittsburgh_Pirates.jpg/190px-Willie_Stargell_-_Pittsburgh_Pirates.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Willie_Stargell_-_Pittsburgh_Pirates.jpg) Hall of Famer [Willie Stargell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willie_Stargell "Willie Stargell") was named [World Series MVP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Series_MVP "World Series MVP") in 1979[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Honus_wagner_t206_baseball_card.jpg/250px-Honus_wagner_t206_baseball_card.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Honus_wagner_t206_baseball_card.jpg) [Honus Wagner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honus_Wagner "Honus Wagner") is considered to be one of the greatest shortstops of all time and was a member of the [MLB Hall of Fame's Inaugural Class in 1936](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Baseball_Hall_of_Fame_and_Museum#Inductees "National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum"). The 1909 [American Tobacco Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Tobacco_Company "American Tobacco Company") card (pictured) is one of the rarest and most expensive baseball cards in the world.

### Pirates Hall of Fame

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Pirates Hall of Fame")\]

In 2022, the Pirates formally established a team Hall of Fame to honor the "most influential ballplayers in Pittsburgh baseball history", as picked by an internal committee that had the help of team historian Jim Trdinich.[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-67)[\[66\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-68) 19 individuals were part of the first class, which included every Pittsburgh Pirate inducted into the [National Baseball Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Baseball_Hall_of_Fame "National Baseball Hall of Fame") along with several other former players, broadcasters, and coaches. Like the Washington Nationals with the [Ring of Honor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Nationals#Ring_of_Honor "Washington Nationals"), the Pirates inducted players that had played for the [Negro league baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negro_league_baseball "Negro league baseball") team [Homestead Grays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homestead_Grays "Homestead Grays"), which had played in [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field") and [Greenlee Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenlee_Field "Greenlee Field") in Pittsburgh alongside their time in Washington; two of the first class also spent time with the [Pittsburgh Crawfords](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Crawfords "Pittsburgh Crawfords"), with a ceremony dedicated to "signing" the four to Pirates contracts. All inductees were honored with a plaque displayed in the concourse by the entrance with the statue of [Roberto Clemente](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Clemente "Roberto Clemente").[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-69)[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-70)

### First-in-MLB accomplishments

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: First-in-MLB accomplishments")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Owen_Wilson%2C_Pittsburgh_Pirates%2C_baseball_card_portrait_LCCN2008676407.jpg/250px-Owen_Wilson%2C_Pittsburgh_Pirates%2C_baseball_card_portrait_LCCN2008676407.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Owen_Wilson,_Pittsburgh_Pirates,_baseball_card_portrait_LCCN2008676407.jpg) [Chief Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Wilson "Chief Wilson") set the MLB all-time record for [triples](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_(baseball) "Triple (baseball)") in a single season in 1912 with 36.

- On May 8, 1886, the Pittsburgh Alleghenys turned the first 3–4–2 triple play in Major League history.[\[83\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-BaseballAlmanac1-85) In the fourth inning of a game, the [Cincinnati Red Stockings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Red_Stockings "Cincinnati Red Stockings") put runners in first and second with no outs. [John Reilly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Reilly_(baseball) "John Reilly (baseball)") grounded out to first base, where [Fred Carroll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Carroll "Fred Carroll") recorded the first out. He threw to second base, where [Sam Barkley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Barkley "Sam Barkley") made the tag for the second out. The runner from second decided to try for home plate and he was cut down on a throw from Barkley and a tag by [Doggie Miller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doggie_Miller "Doggie Miller").\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] The Alleghenys won the game, 9–6.[\[84\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-BaseballReference1-86)
- First ever Major League Baseball game broadcast on the radio, a game between the Pirates and the host [Philadelphia Phillies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies "Philadelphia Phillies") aired August 5, 1921, on [KDKA (AM)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KDKA_(AM) "KDKA (AM)") Pittsburgh. The Pirates won the game, 8–5.
- In [1925](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_World_Series "1925 World Series"), the Pirates became the first MLB team to recover from a 3-games-to-1 deficit in winning a best-of-seven World Series; they then became the first MLB team to repeat that feat in [1979](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_World_Series "1979 World Series").[\[85\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-87)[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-88)
- During the 1953 season, the Pirates became the first team to permanently adopt batting helmets on both offense and defense. These helmets resembled a primitive fiberglass " [miner's cap](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coal_miner "Coal miner")". This was the mandate of general manager [Branch Rickey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_Rickey "Branch Rickey"), who also owned stock in the company producing the helmets. Under Rickey's orders, all Pirate players had to wear the helmets both at bat and in the field. The helmets became a permanent feature for all Pirate hitters, but within a few weeks the team began to abandon their use of helmets in the field, partly because of their awkward and heavy feel. Once the Pirates discarded the helmets on defense, the trend disappeared from the game.[\[87\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-89) In 2014, Major League Baseball allowed pitchers to choose to wear a padded hat that aims to combine the added safety of a helmet with the comfort of a baseball cap.[\[88\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-90) The cap would prove widely unpopular, with only [Alex Torres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Torres_(baseball) "Alex Torres (baseball)") of the [New York Mets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Mets "New York Mets") choosing to wear it.[\[89\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-91)
- First franchise to win a World Series on a [home run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walk-off_home_run "Walk-off home run") ( [1960 World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1960_World_Series "1960 World Series")) in the 7th game. The only other team to accomplish this feat is the [Toronto Blue Jays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_Toronto_Blue_Jays_season "1993 Toronto Blue Jays season") in [1993](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_World_Series "1993 World Series"), though theirs came in Game 6.
- In [1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970_in_baseball "1970 in baseball") the Pirates became the first major league club to create their uniforms using a cotton-nylon blend featuring pull-over shirts and beltless pants.[\[90\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-92)
- The first all-minority lineup in MLB history took the field on September 1, 1971.[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-93) The lineup was [Rennie Stennett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rennie_Stennett "Rennie Stennett"), [Gene Clines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_Clines "Gene Clines"), [Roberto Clemente](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Clemente "Roberto Clemente"), [Willie Stargell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willie_Stargell "Willie Stargell"), [Manny Sanguillén](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manny_Sanguill%C3%A9n "Manny Sanguillén"), [Dave Cash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Cash_(baseball) "Dave Cash (baseball)"), [Al Oliver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Oliver "Al Oliver"), [Jackie Hernández](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackie_Hern%C3%A1ndez "Jackie Hernández"), and [Dock Ellis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dock_Ellis "Dock Ellis").[\[92\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-autogenerated1-94)
- The first World Series night game was played in [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium") on October 13, 1971— [eleven years to the day since Mazeroski's walk-off homer brought the Pirates their last World Series title in 1960](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_sports_lore#Mazeroski's_Home_Run "Pittsburgh sports lore"). In this case, however, it was Game 4 between the Pirates and the Baltimore Orioles, rather than a decisive Game 7. Apparently, good things happen for the Pirates on this date, as they knotted the [1971 World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_World_Series "1971 World Series") at two games apiece on their way to their fourth title.
- The first MLB scout to win the "Scout of the Year Award", [Howie Haak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howie_Haak "Howie Haak"), in 1984, three additional scouts from the organization have subsequently won the award.
- The first combined [extra inning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extra_innings "Extra innings") [no-hitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No-hitter "No-hitter") in MLB history took place at Three Rivers Stadium on July 12, 1997. [Francisco Córdova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_C%C3%B3rdova_(baseball,_born_1972) "Francisco Córdova (baseball, born 1972)") (9 innings) and [Ricardo Rincón](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ricardo_Rinc%C3%B3n "Ricardo Rincón") (1 inning) combined to no-hit the [Houston Astros](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1997_Houston_Astros_season "1997 Houston Astros season"), 3–0 in 10 innings. [Pinch-hitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinch-hitter "Pinch-hitter") [Mark Smith's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Smith_(outfielder) "Mark Smith (outfielder)") three-run [walk-off home run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walk-off_home_run "Walk-off home run") in the bottom of the 10th inning sealed the victory and the no-hitter for the Pirates. It remains the only such no-hitter to date.[\[93\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-95)
- In November 2008, the Pirates became the first MLB team to sign Indian players when they acquired the non-draft free agents of [Rinku Singh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rinku_Singh_(wrestler) "Rinku Singh (wrestler)") and [Dinesh Patel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dinesh_Patel "Dinesh Patel").[\[94\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-pittsburgh.pirates.mlb.com-96)[\[95\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-97) This was also seen by Pirates [general manager](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_manager_(baseball) "General manager (baseball)") [Neal Huntington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neal_Huntington "Neal Huntington"), as "not only add\[ing\] two prospects to our system but also hope to open a pathway to an untapped market."[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-98)
- The Pirates are the first team in professional sports to have 20 consecutive losing seasons. This streak lasted from 1993 to 2012. This is the longest such streak in North American professional sports history.
- The Pirates are the first MLB team (as well as only second in major professional sports) to be owned by an [openly gay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gay "Gay") owner, although [Kevin McClatchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_McClatchy "Kevin McClatchy") had already divested his shares in the Pirates when he openly announced his homosexuality in September 2012.[\[97\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-Coming_Out_in_the_World_of_Sports-99)[\[98\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-100)
- On April 6, 2015, the Pirates' loss to the [Cincinnati Reds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds "Cincinnati Reds") earned the team its 10,000 franchise loss and making the Pirates the first MLB team to reach their 10,000th loss on an Opening Day.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-Wilmoth,_Charlie_2015-18)
- On May 9, 2015, the Pirates became the first MLB team to turn a 4–5–4 triple play. The triple play occurred during a 7–5 win over the [St. Louis Cardinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis Cardinals"). The play occurred when the Cardinals' [Yadier Molina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yadier_Molina "Yadier Molina") lined out to Pittsburgh second baseman [Neil Walker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_Walker_(baseball) "Neil Walker (baseball)"). Walker then threw to third baseman [Jung Ho Kang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jung_Ho_Kang "Jung Ho Kang") to double off the Cardinals' [Jhonny Peralta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jhonny_Peralta "Jhonny Peralta") for the second out. Kang then threw the ball back to Walker, who was standing on second base for the final out after St. Louis's [Jason Heyward](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_Heyward "Jason Heyward") froze between second and third.[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-101)
- On April 24, 2017, the Pirates fielded the first baseball player to be born and raised in [Lithuania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithuania "Lithuania"), to reach the major leagues, [Dovydas Neverauskas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dovydas_Neverauskas "Dovydas Neverauskas"). In 1933, [Joe Zapustas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Zapustas "Joe Zapustas") was the first Lithuanian-born player to play in MLB, as a member of the Philadelphia Athletics, however, he grew up in Boston.[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-102)
- On April 26, 2017, the Pirates promoted [South African](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") [Gift Ngoepe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gift_Ngoepe "Gift Ngoepe") from the AAA [Indianapolis Indians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indianapolis_Indians "Indianapolis Indians"); making him the first African-born player in MLB history.[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-103)
- On August 23, 2017, the Pirates became the first team in MLB history to break up a no-hitter in extra innings with a [walk-off home run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walk-off_home_run "Walk-off home run"). The home run was hit by [Josh Harrison](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josh_Harrison "Josh Harrison") in the tenth inning, off pitcher [Rich Hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rich_Hill_(pitcher) "Rich Hill (pitcher)"), to give the Pirates a 1–0 win over the [Los Angeles Dodgers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_Dodgers "Los Angeles Dodgers").[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-104)
