## Civil rights advocacy

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Civil rights advocacy")\]

Throughout the 1940s Pirates owner [William Benswanger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Benswanger "William Benswanger") was a leading advocate of integration of the Major Leagues, once planning a tryout for African American players to sign up for the club.[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-106)

The Pirates organization was the first in baseball to have both an African-American coach and manager, when [Gene Baker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_Baker "Gene Baker") broke the color line in 1961 and 1962 respectively. On September 21, 1963, the Pirates were the first MLB team to have an African-American manager in Gene Baker, as he filled in for Danny Murtaugh.[\[105\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-107)

On September 1, 1971, manager Murtaugh assembled a starting lineup that was completely composed of minority players for the first time in MLB history.[\[106\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-108)

## Fanbase

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Fanbase")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Bing_Crosby_1951.jpg/250px-Bing_Crosby_1951.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bing_Crosby_1951.jpg) [Bing Crosby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bing_Crosby "Bing Crosby") co-owned the Pirates from 1946 until his death in 1977.

Even though they have had some notable fans including former part-owner [Bing Crosby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bing_Crosby "Bing Crosby"), [Michael Keaton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Keaton "Michael Keaton"), and [Regis Philbin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regis_Philbin "Regis Philbin"),[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-109) the Pirates are considered by most to be a distant third in Pittsburgh behind the [Pittsburgh Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") and [Pittsburgh Penguins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins") in popularity among Pittsburgh's three [major professional sports teams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_professional_sports_leagues_in_the_United_States_and_Canada "Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada").[\[108\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-110) However, due to their long history in Pittsburgh dating back to the 1882 season, the team has retained a strong loyal following in the Pittsburgh region, especially among older residents. Upon the team ending their 20-season losing season streak with a winning season in [2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "2013 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), the fan support for the club has grown once again but still remaining a distant third behind the city's other 2 more successful franchises in the last half-century.

While the team's recent struggles compared to Pittsburgh's other two teams can be partly to blame (since the Pirates last World Series championship in 1979, the Steelers have won the [Super Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl") three times ( [XIV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XIV "Super Bowl XIV"), [XL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XL "Super Bowl XL"), and [XLIII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLIII "Super Bowl XLIII")) and the Penguins the [Stanley Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanley_Cup "Stanley Cup") five times in [1991](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1991_Stanley_Cup_Final "1991 Stanley Cup Final"), [1992](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992_Stanley_Cup_Final "1992 Stanley Cup Final"), [2009](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Stanley_Cup_Final "2009 Stanley Cup Final"), [2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Stanley_Cup_Final "2016 Stanley Cup Final"), and [2017](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Stanley_Cup_Final "2017 Stanley Cup Final"), including both in 2009), distractions off the field have also caused the team's popularity to slip in the city. While the team was ranked first in Pittsburgh as recent as the late 1970s,[\[109\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-111) the [Pittsburgh drug trials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_drug_trials "Pittsburgh drug trials") in 1985 and two relocation threats since are believed to have also seen the team's popularity dipped.[\[110\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-112) The team's standing among fans has, however, improved along with the team on the field and the opening of [PNC Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Park "PNC Park") in 2001.[\[111\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-113) Following the [Andrew McCutchen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_McCutchen "Andrew McCutchen") trade in 2018, fan relations have deteriorated despite the Pirates contending for the NL Central during 2018 due to backlash towards owner [Robert Nutting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Nutting "Robert Nutting"), with the team ranking 27th among 30 MLB team in attendance that season.[\[112\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-114)

When the Penguins won the Stanley Cup in 2009 captain [Sidney Crosby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_Crosby "Sidney Crosby") brought the cup to PNC Park on the Sunday following the team's victory in [Detroit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit "Detroit"). When they won again in 2017 the cup was once again brought to PNC Park and the team threw out the first pitch. The team won the cup in 1992 and they held a celebration in the Pirates' old home [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium").

## Community activities

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Community activities")\]

Each year, the Pirates recognize six "Community Champions" during a special pregame ceremony.[\[113\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-115)

**Piratefest** is a yearly event that is held by the Pittsburgh Pirates in January. The event is, in essence, a baseball carnival for the whole family. It features autograph sessions from current and former Pirates players and coaches, live events and games, carnival booths, baseball clinics, "Ask Pirates Management", and appearances by the [Pirate Parrot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirate_Parrot "Pirate Parrot"). Piratefest was once held at the [David L. Lawrence Convention Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_L._Lawrence_Convention_Center "David L. Lawrence Convention Center") in downtown Pittsburgh[\[114\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-116) but is now held annually at the ballpark.

## Media

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Media")\]

Further information: [Pittsburgh Pirates Radio Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates_Radio_Network "Pittsburgh Pirates Radio Network") and [List of Pittsburgh Pirates broadcasters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_Pirates_broadcasters "List of Pittsburgh Pirates broadcasters")

### Radio and TV

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Radio and TV")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Pittsburgh_Pirates_radio_affiliates.png/330px-Pittsburgh_Pirates_radio_affiliates.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pittsburgh_Pirates_radio_affiliates.png) Map of Pirate radio affiliates

The Pirates broadcast the first ever baseball game over the radio on August 5, 1921. [Harold Arlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Arlin "Harold Arlin"), a foreman at [Westinghouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westinghouse_Electric_Corporation "Westinghouse Electric Corporation"), announced the game over [KDKA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KDKA_(AM) "KDKA (AM)") from a box seat next to the first base [dugout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dugout_(baseball) "Dugout (baseball)") at [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field").[\[115\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-117)[\[116\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-Voices-118) KDKA had received its broadcasting license only nine months before, becoming the first commercially licensed radio station in the world. Pirate games would be sporadically broadcast over the radio for the next decade; regular broadcasts began in the mid-1930s, with [Rosey Rowswell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosey_Rowswell "Rosey Rowswell") becoming the voice of the Pirates in 1936.[\[117\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-119) Except for a few years on [WWSW](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WBGG_(AM) "WBGG (AM)") in the late 1940s and early 1950s, the Pirates were on KDKA for 61 years. KDKA's 50,000-watt [clear channel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clear-channel_station "Clear-channel station") enabled Pirates fans across the eastern half of North America at night to hear the games.

In 2007, the Pirates chose to end the longest relationship between a team and a radio station in American professional sports and moved to FM [talk radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk_radio "Talk radio") station [WPGB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPGB "WPGB"). The Pirates cited the desire to reach more people in the 25–54 age bracket coveted by advertisers. The acquisition of the rights means that [Clear Channel Communications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clear_Channel_Communications "Clear Channel Communications") holds the rights to every major sports team in Pittsburgh. The Pirates have long had a radio network that has extended across four states. Stations for the 2007 season included Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Ohio, and Maryland radio broadcasters.[\[118\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-120)

On October 1, 2011, Clear Channel announced that they would not renew their deal with the Pirates, and the team shortly thereafter announced a deal to transfer back to [CBS Radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_Radio "CBS Radio") via FM [sports radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_radio "Sports radio") station [KDKA-FM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KDKA-FM "KDKA-FM"),[\[119\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-121) which became official on October 12.[\[120\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-122)
On March 2, 2016, it was announced a new deal was reached for the Pirates to remain on KDKA-FM.[\[121\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-123) As part of the deal, KDKA-AM has returned as essentially the AM flagship of the team, simulcasting all weekday afternoon games, select other broadcasts, and serving as the backup station for any games that KDKA-FM can not air due to conflicts with [Pittsburgh Panthers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers "Pittsburgh Panthers") football and men's basketball.[\[122\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-124)

Games are televised on [SportsNet Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SportsNet_Pittsburgh "SportsNet Pittsburgh"), the Pirates' cable television outlet since 1986, when it was known as KBL. The network is majority owned by [Fenway Sports Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fenway_Sports_Group "Fenway Sports Group"), owners of the [Boston Red Sox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Red_Sox "Boston Red Sox") and [Pittsburgh Penguins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins"). The Pirates became joint owners of the channel on December 16, 2023, with operations to be produced by the Red Sox's home network [NESN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NESN "NESN").[\[123\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-125) During the 2016 season, the Pirates averaged a 7.22 rating and 83,000 viewers on primetime TV broadcasts.[\[124\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-126) Apart from any Pirates games aired nationally on Fox, there has been no over-the-air coverage of the Pirates since 2002. Previously, [KDKA-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KDKA-TV "KDKA-TV") aired Pirates games for 38 years (1957–1994). Games also aired on [WPXI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPXI "WPXI") (1995–1996) and on [WPGH-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPGH-TV "WPGH-TV") and WCWB (1997–2002).

### Announcers

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Announcers")\]

**Current**

The Pirates have no set broadcast team for radio or TV; instead, all announcers and analysts take turns working in both mediums over the course of a season. The longest-tenured broadcasters are play-by-play announcer [Greg Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Brown_(broadcaster) "Greg Brown (broadcaster)") and analyst [Bob Walk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Walk "Bob Walk"), both of whom joined the broadcast booth in 1994. Former Pirate and Pittsburgh native [John Wehner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Wehner "John Wehner") joined the crew in 2005 as an analyst,[\[125\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-127) while [Joe Block](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Block "Joe Block") became the team's second play-by-play announcer in 2016 after previously working for the [Milwaukee Brewers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milwaukee_Brewers "Milwaukee Brewers").[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-128) Former Pirate players who have recently filled in as analysts include [Matt Capps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Capps "Matt Capps"), [Kevin Young](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Young_(baseball) "Kevin Young (baseball)"), and [Neil Walker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_Walker "Neil Walker").

**Past**

Westinghouse Electric foreman [Harold Arlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Arlin "Harold Arlin") called the first-ever radio broadcast of a baseball game, an 8-5 Phillies victory over the Pirates on August 5, 1921. A rotating group of announcers would call games over the next 15 years until Rosey Rowswell joined the broadcast team in 1936. Rowswell did not travel with the team for road games, instead re-creating the action in Pittsburgh after it came in over the [teleprinter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teleprinter "Teleprinter"), usually an inning or so behind. After working solo for a decade, he was joined in the booth by [Bob Prince](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Prince "Bob Prince") in 1947; Prince would become the lead play-by-play man after Rowswell died in February 1955.[\[127\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-ref1986-129) Prince's broadcasting style made him immensely popular with fans, and his almost 30-year run with the club coincided with the Pirates' rise to a championship-caliber team.[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-130)[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-131) Nicknamed "The Gunner," Prince was known for his "Gunnerisms"—nicknames and quips—and created the [Green Weenie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Weenie "Green Weenie") in 1966. He also called the Pirates' championships in [1960](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1960_World_Series "1960 World Series") and [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_World_Series "1971 World Series") as part of the national broadcast for [NBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC "NBC").

Prince and his broadcast partner [Nellie King](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nellie_King "Nellie King") were fired in 1975, which drew the ire of the Pirates' fanbase. [Milo Hamilton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milo_Hamilton "Milo Hamilton") and [Lanny Frattare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanny_Frattare "Lanny Frattare") took over as the new broadcast team in 1976. Hamilton was unhappy in Pittsburgh; he didn't get along with Frattare and felt that he was being criticized for not being Bob Prince.[\[130\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-132) Hamilton left to join the [Chicago Cubs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Cubs "Chicago Cubs") after the 1979 season, and Frattare was elevated to the lead play-by-play announcer. Frattare would continue to call Pirate games through the 2008 season, becoming the longest tenured play-by-play man in team history. In turn, he was replaced by [Tim Neverett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Neverett "Tim Neverett"), who called Pirate games from 2009 through 2015.[\[131\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-133)

Former analysts include [Don Hoak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Hoak "Don Hoak"), [Nelson Briles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Briles "Nelson Briles"), and [Jim Rooker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Rooker "Jim Rooker"). Former Pirate pitcher [Steve Blass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Blass "Steve Blass"), who won Game 7 of the 1971 World Series, worked as a color analyst for the team from 1983 to 2019.[\[132\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-134)
